beer.desc: The beer was named Bracken’s Porter as a tribute to our favourite four pawed friend who sadly passed in 2013. Chocolately, robust, warming, laid back and lots of fun - there are plenty of similarities between the two. Bracken we miss you and we hope you like your beer. Long live the original BrewDog.
food: Grilled vegetable and chicken teriyaki skewers
beer.name: Bracken's Porter
beer.tagline: A Tribute To Our Favourite 4 Pawed Friend.
beer.tips: Try to replicate London’s highly carbonated water to really emphasise the dark malt profile.

beer.desc: Good old Bramling Cross is elegant, refined, assured, (boring) and understated. Understated that is unless you hop the living daylights out of a beer with it. This is Bramling Cross re-invented and re-imagined, and shows just what can be done with English hops if you use enough of them. Poor Bramling Cross normally gets lost in a woeful stream of conformist brown ales made by sleepy cask ale brewers. But not anymore. This beer shows that British hops do have some soul, and is a fruity riot of blackberries, pears, and plums. Reminds me of the bramble, apple and ginger jam my grandmother used to make.
food: Aromatic korma curry with lemon and garlic naan
beer.name: Bramling X
beer.tips: Getting good Bramling Cross is key. Most English hops are in leaf form (not pelletised), so getting fresh hops close to harvest (September) will give this beer the right amount of dark berry intensity.

beer.desc: Never Mind the Anabolics, a 6.5% India Pale Ale brewed with copious amounts of performance-enhancing natural ingredients. Brewed to commemorate the 2012 Olympics and its merry marketing bandwagon.
food: Grilled chicken salad with bacon and avocado
Red pepper houmous and flat bread
beer.name: Never Mind The Anabolics
beer.tips: Mix the powders into a paste before adding to the wort kettle. This will prevent the powders from balling up and not bringing the full flavour effect.

beer.desc: This is East Kent Goldings re- invented and re-imagined and shows just what can be done with English hops if you use enough of them. In this amped up Goldings reincarnation expect to be slammed with floral lavender, a fruity riot of blackberries and spiced pears, bubblegum, plums and the illusion of thyme.
beer.name: Goldings - IPA Is Dead
beer.tips: Take a read through each year’s hop harvest that is available. Some years are better than others.

beer.desc: Brewed in collaboration with Soren from New Zealand’s stellar 8-Wired brewery, this is an Imperial Pilsner featuring two of our favourite New Zealand hops: Nelson Sauvin and Motueka. Sitting at a dangerously drinkable 7.1% ABV there’s a touch of Munich malt which gives this beer that little extra caramel biscuit bite to compliment the lip smackingly tropical hops. Expect an all out NZ hoppy riot.
beer.name: Dog Wired (w/8 Wired)
beer.tips: Hold the mash for longer at 63-64°C to get more fermentability from the wort.

beer.desc: An imperial stout brewed with cacao and coffee, AB22 has spent two years in darkness, drawing complex and indulgent flavours from the Speyside whisky casks in which it resided.
beer.name: AB:22
beer.tips: Soak American oak (medium toasted) chips in your favourite Speyside tipple overnight and add them after primary fermentation

beer.desc: Wonderfully tart, bitter, piney and filled with the fruity elements from raspberries, blueberries and sour cherries. Oh, and it’s purple.
beer.name: Lizard Bride - Prototype Challenge
beer.tips: Try to find the ripest berries possible to impart as much juicy goodness as possible. These can be forzen until you have the full set.

beer.desc: 2015 IPA is Dead Series. Supremely floral, this hugely under-rated hop is related to Galaxy and was first cultivated in the Australian state of Victoria. Initially given the same name as a certain Eurolager, their lawyers got involved and the St- prefix was dropped. Ella displays subtle notes of spice, but is fundamentally a truly floral bouquet, redolent of the Southern Hemisphere.
food: Cheddar cheese toastie on dark rye
Lamb samosas with chilli dipping sauce
beer.name: Ella - IPA Is Dead
beer.tips: These beers need to hit FG to really pop. If you're fermentation is struggling, whip up a starter and re-pitch to get some viable yeast in there to finish the job

beer.desc: Hardcore IPA with raspberries aged in Caol Ila casks. Full-bodied and compelling, the robust malt base provides an initial layer of honey, cinnamon and biscuity malt sweetness. Soon the Scottish berries are in on the act, a dominating tug of war between sweet and tart with an overbearing zest. As the beer slips back across your tongue the hops demand and definitely get your attention. At 100 IBUs the bitterness smashes into the back of your throat as the resinous, spiced orange peel flavours add depth to the berry fruitiness.
beer.name: Prototype 27
beer.tips: Soak some oak chips in Caol Ila whisky to get barrel character. Freeze raspberries before adding them to secondary.

beer.desc: A fresh tropical hit from this Black IPA, with undertones of roasted coffee. A well balanced, drinkable yet complex beer.
food: Spicy carne asada with black beans and Mexican Rice
beer.name: Black Eye Joe (w/ Stone Brewing Co)
beer.tips: Be careful to select the right coffee for this brew. For a fresh but fruity coffee hit, try to find lightly roasted Arabica beans.

beer.desc: This Old World Stout perfectly recreates the export stouts of years gone by; brewed to imperial strength to avoid freezing during its journey across the Baltic Sea to snowy Moscow. Full bodied with huge chocolate, coffee and roast flavours, this imperial stout employs a variety of hops to add enough bitterness and hop complexity to balance the huge malt sweetness and rich mocha and molasses flavours.
food: Seared steak with a peppercorn sauce
beer.name: Old World Russian Imperial Stout
beer.tips: Add the chocolate malt after the mash is complete, at the start of sparging. This will extract flavour and colour, but will prevent the extraction of harsh tannins into the wort.

beer.desc: Our Unleash the Yeast series was an epic experiment into the differences in aroma and flavour provided by switching up your yeast. We brewed up a wort with a light caramel note and some toasty biscuit flavour, and hopped it with Amarillo and Centennial for a citrusy bitterness. Everything else is down to the yeast. Bavarian Weizen yeast adds traditional weissbier notes of banana and clove.
food: German bratwurst with spicy mustard dip and vinaigrette salad
beer.name: Bavarian Weizen
beer.tips: Play around with the fermentation temperature to get the best flavour profile from the individual yeasts.

beer.desc: This is the Vietnamese Coffee Edition. At 12.7% ABV, Black Eyed King Imp is a super intense and twistedly complex brew, with intense notes of sweet vanilla, rich espresso, smooth molasses and bitter chocolate barely contained by the whatever container it's in.
beer.name: Black Eyed King Imp - Vietnamese Coffee Edition
beer.tips: Buying top notch coffee beans make a huge difference here. Give them a very course grind to get the most out of them.

beer.desc: This mezcal-inspired brew is the shipwrecked remains of a collaboration brewed with former craft brewers Ballast Point. Brewed to encapsulate the flavours of mezcal, this beer smoulders with peaty and light woody notes, as well as intense fruity character.
beer.name: Ship Wreck
beer.tips: Nail your colours to the mother fucking mast – independence or death.

beer.desc: A potently bitter hop variety originally grown in the US around 40 years ago, Comet has been newly resurrected - this German version has bold resinous grapefruit flavours, which add a huge fresh hop aroma to this IPA.
food: Panna cotta with a grapefruit tuile
beer.name: Comet
beer.tips: Experiment with other high alpha hops during dry-hop to discover their aroma and flavour characteristics.

beer.desc: No Label is a postmodern, postgender non-binary brew; the world’s first beer made with transgender hops. Brewed with whole hop bines that have spontaneously changed from female to male, no label goes its own way. No Label balances a light, biscuity dryness from the malt base with delicate hints of fruity esters gifted by the fermentation. Finally, dry- hopping adds a layer of new world tropical & pine flavours that add a unique twist to this classic Kölsch style beer. All profits from the sales of this beer were donated to LGBTQI+ events organisers Queerest of the Queer.
food: Strawberry and basil salad with feta
beer.name: No Label
beer.tips: Dry hop using a muslin bag in order to give you the best chance at getting the signature Kölsch clarity.

Poor Bramling Cross normally gets lost in a woeful stream of conformist brown ales made by sleepy cask ale brewers. But not anymore. This beer shows that British hops do have some soul, and is a fruity riot of blackberries, pears, and plums. Reminds me of the bramble, apple and ginger jam my grandmother used to make.
food: Aromatic korma curry with lemon and garlic naan
beer.name: Bramling X
beer.tips: Getting good Bramling Cross is key. Most English hops are in leaf form (not pelletised), so getting fresh hops close to harvest (September) will give this beer the right amount of dark berry intensity.

beer.desc: Jack Hammer has been single handedly ripping it up for quite some time. Now, the definitive bitter and twisted IPA, has spawned four Hammer Head off-springs. Black Hammer is the second of our hyped up hybrid IPAs. A black hearted beast, that takes no prisoners. American hops and dark malt combine to make mischief. Grapefruit and coffee collide in sensory overload – a wake-up call for other IPA’s. Molten waves of pithy grapefruit build and finally ebb to the roasty bitter onslaught. Stand  firm and wield the Black Hammer with care. Stare into the black abyss and succumb to the dark-side.
food: Buffalo wings with blue cheese dip
beer.name: Black Hammer
beer.tagline: Our Ruthless IPA With A Dark Malt Twist.
beer.tips: You may have to leave this beer on dry hops for slightly longer than usual to let the flavours balance.

beer.desc: Re-brewed as a spring seasonal, this beer – which appeared originally as an Equity Punk shareholder creation – retains its trademark spicy, fruity edge. A perfect blend of Belgian Saison and US IPA, crushed peppercorns and heather honey are also added to produce a genuinely unique beer.
food: Mussels with a garlic and herb sauce
beer.name: Electric India
beer.tips: Source some really good heather honey to get the right spicy esters in the beer.

beer.desc: Welcome aboard our experimental range of tuned IPAs. Buckle up for an explosive sensory bombardment. Tropical fruit and resinous pine are primed. The first wave of pineapple, melon and mango quickly accelerate into a afterburner of candied citrus fruit and sweet caramel. Sonic Boom - IPA turning at the speed of sound.
beer.name: Sonic Boom
beer.tips: This IPA features German hops in the dry hop. Why not try a Slovenian only version using: Dana, Bobek, Aurora & Cascade.

beer.desc: Spiced peppercorn and rhubarb Saison.
beer.name: Rhubarb Saison - B-Sides
beer.tips: Be prepared to give your Saison yeast plenty of time to do its thing. It’s not unheard of for Saison fermentation taking 6-8 weeks.

beer.desc: Savagely bitter, exceptionally dry, this IPA is born to die on a predetermined day. It proudly displays its short-lived life span front and centre. There is no better time to drink this than the moment you get your paws on it. Awesome bitterness backed up by unrelenting aromas of resin, citrus, and juicy fruit. Born To Die is a eulogy to the hops that sacrificed themselves in its creation. An incredibly ambitious and satisfying small batch brew.
food: Caramelised onion and lightly seared steak
beer.name: Born To Die
beer.tips: Fresh is best with this beer. Use fresh hops in the brew and during dry hop stages. Condition just long enough to let the powerful grassy aroma cut back - and drink.

beer.desc: AB:21 is a liquorice and blackcurrant infused imperial stout. Rolling in at an imposing 12% abv, this huge and decadent dark beer dials down the charred roastiness and focuses instead on the rich, full-bodied chocolate and dark fruit character of the style.
beer.name: AB:21
beer.tips: As with all of our Abstrakts this one is great for ageing. Be extra vigilant at all times as a small fault now will lead to disaster a few years down the line.

beer.desc: A new 5% Pilsner, that feaures in Fanzine, our new subscription model.
beer.name: Zipcode
beer.tips: Saphir hops are not widespread at the moment if you cannot get hold of any, a good batch of Mittlefruh is a fair substitute.

beer.desc: Brewed exclusively for the Swedish market, this Hello My Name brew features a twist of flavour inspired by Sweden.
beer.name: Hello My Name Is Agnetha
beer.tips: Add the lingonberry juice either to the end of the boil or to the fermenter, depending on whether the juice has been pasteurised.

beer.desc: A hop that tastes of bubble gum? Seriously? No, we did not believe it either. But it does! This is one unique, son of a bitch of a hop. Lemony, deep, musty with a smoothness that belies its power. This hop is lemony like a lemon who was angry earlier but is now tired because of all the rage. This hop of Japanese origin is best enjoyed trying to make sushi from your gold fish, or trying to persuade your girlfriend (or boyfriend maybe) to dress up as a Geisha for Valentine’s Day.
food: Grilled salmon with a herb and citrus infused butter
Basil, lemon and pine nut angel hair pasta with grilled chicken
beer.name: Sorachi Ace
beer.tips: Sorachi Ace is hop best handled with care. Too much and your beer may taste like dill pickle and lemons.

beer.desc: Think bakewell tart with Christmas spices.
food: Wild rice salad with wild mushrooms
beer.name: Spiced Cherry Sour - B-Sides
beer.tips: In the boil: cinnamon, star anise, clove, guinea pepper. After fermentation add: raspberry puree, cherry concentrate, bitter almond extract, American oak chips and Tahitian vanilla beans.

beer.desc: Trashy Blonde with a Belgian Twist. Clove oil, red apples and a drier mouthfeel set this beer apart from its older sister.
beer.name: Eurotrash
beer.tips: Don't be scared to let the fermentation temperature climb up another couple of degrees to really emphasize the Belgian character.

beer.desc: Pilot Brew: A twist on an English Bitter style beer, using Sorachi Ace hops throughout making a showcase of the off the dill and lemon character.
beer.name: Sorachi Bitter - B-Sides
beer.tips: The touch of rye adds a great touch of spice that plays off the hops really well.

beer.desc: An avalanche of cross-continental hop varieties give this porter a complex spicy, resinous and citrusy aroma, with a huge malt bill providing a complex roasty counterpoint. Digging deeper into the flavour draws out cinder toffee, bitter chocolate and hints of woodsmoke.
beer.name: Libertine Porter
beer.tips: Mash in at a higher temperature to leave more unfermentable sugars in the wort. This gives the beer a sweeter porter profile.

beer.desc: Our first 2018 Wildcard brew, Kamikaze Knitting Club is a one-off brew. A maple stout, Kamikaze combines dark malts with a classic Canadian export, adding to the warming malty and smokey character.
beer.name: Kamikaze Knitting Club
beer.tips: Try experimenting with fenugreek seeds which give off a maple syrup like flavour.

beer.desc: A vermont style IPA, with low background bitterness, loaded with intense juicy fruit character.
beer.name: Small Batch: Vermont IPA
beer.tips: Add the dry hops in separate muslin bags to increase surface area contact and reduce the amount of hop matter in the beer after dry hopping without reducing the characteristic hazy look of the beer.

beer.desc: In this northern German style retro altbier, we’ve dialled down the dry-hops to zero, but cranked up the malt to create massive aromas. Toasty, toffee and floral notes duke it out for supremacy in the headspace of your glass. When this all hits your palate, the steely bitterness combines with the rich dry malt and the subtle alcohol warmth in a full throttle attack on your taste buds.
beer.name: Candy Kaiser
beer.tips: Make sure that the boil is vigorous enough to roll. This means that high flavours are active, and undesirable compounds like DMS are not left in the beer.

beer.desc: An Imperial Black Belgian Ale aged in old Invergordon Scotch whisky barrels with mountains of raspberries, tayberries and blackberries in each cask. Decadent but light and dry, this beer would make a fantastic base for ageing on pretty much any dark fruit - we used raspberries, tayberries and blackberries beause they were local.
food: Beef Wellington with a red wine jus
beer.name: AB:12
beer.tips: Don't worry too much about controlling the temperature with the Belgian yeast strain - just make sure it doesn't rise above 30°C!

beer.desc: Brewed exclusively for the Irish market, this Hello My Name brew features a twist of flavour inspired by Ireland.
beer.name: Hello My Name Is Niamh
beer.tips: Save yourself a lot of hassle and buy the Elderflower as a concentrate or cordial. Collecting elderberries ranks low on the FPES (fruit picking enjoyment scale), can't imagine the flower picking is much better.

beer.desc: Old world meets new in this trans-atlantic mash up of brewing ingredients. Belgian funk incorporates itself into the pithy, resin and grapefruit, with pineapple and banana rounding out a rambunctious avalanche of fruity hops.
beer.name: Punk Monk
beer.tips: Bottle condition and prime with a little bit more sugar than usual to attain those authentic fine Belgian bubbles.

beer.desc: Scottish chocolate breakfast Stout - brewed with Brazilian Sertão coffee, Venezuelan cacao and (for the Scottish element) oatmeal. Smooth, chocolately and rich, with a honeycomb mouthfeel and a rich red berry coffee character. Brewed with our beer blogger friends from The Beer Cast and Hopzine.
beer.name: Dead Metaphor
beer.tips: Steep the cocoa nibs and chocolate in the hot wort for a short period for the best extraction of flavour compounds.

beer.desc: The levels of hops vary throughout the range. We love hops, so all four beers are big, bitter badasses, but by tweaking the amount of each hop used later in the boil and during dry- hopping, we can balance the malty backbone with some unexpected flavours. Simcoe is used in the whirlpool for all four beers, and yet still lends different characters to each.
food: Roast chicken with vegetables and wild rice
Fresh pico de gallo with corn tortilla
beer.name: Pale - Russian Doll
beer.tips: Create balance through experimentation with the hop amounts and malt backbone.

beer.desc: This recreated the epic IPAs that were sent on monumental ocean voyages from England to India by sea in the 1800s. Medium bodied with a complex malt profile, backed up with intense bitterness and a woodsy, earthy rich English hop character.
food: Honey glazed ham with spicy roasted carrots
beer.name: Old World India Pale Ale
beer.tips: In beers like this with a hefty malt bill, it pays to check a spoonful of the mash with some iodine solution. This will indicate if the mash has converted all of the starch into fermentable sugars. If the colour is very dark, just extend the mash rest by 10 mins and check again.

beer.desc: Flavours and aromas you'd expect from a Stout, but brewed without dark malts. The full mouthfeel comes courtesy of wheat and oats, while smoked malt and the twist additions add the complex flavours normally provided by highly kilned malts.
food: Caramelised scallops with burnt apple puree
beer.name: AB:08
beer.tips: Add all twist ingredients to Fermentation Vessel once fermentation is complete. Don’t be afraid to add a little at a time and taste as you go. During mashing in first start with pale malt. Afterwards mix all malts evenly. Go with flaked oats during second half of mashing in process.

beer.desc: Jack Hammer has been single handedly ripping it up for quite some time. Now, the definitive bitter and twisted IPA, has spawned four Hammer Head off-springs. Monk Hammer is the first of our super-charge hyped up hybrids. A dark cloaked holy man packing an unholy punch. Belgian yeast and American hops untie on a cardinal scale. Steel yourself for biblical volumes of grapefruit, bow your head for a wave of spicy, fruity yeast character, then cross yourself for the bitterest of bitter finishes. Let your senses succumb to this 21st century incarnation. Monk Hammer – worship daily.
beer.name: Monk Hammer
beer.tagline: Our Ruthless IPA With A Belgian Twist.
beer.tips: Oxygen is critical for this strain of yeast so make sure you aerate your wort properly.

beer.desc: This French white wine barrel aged Imperial Saison has a plethora of intertwining flavours. Huge aromas of peach, syrup, tangerine, sherry, toffee and raisin, followed by a dynamic bracing acidity.
beer.name: Everday Anarchy
beer.tagline: White Wine Barrel-Aged Imperial Red Saison.
beer.tips: The honey addition will help to dry out the beer, as the saison yeast will continue to ferment long after most ale yeast.

beer.desc: Our Unleash the Yeast series was an epic experiment into the differences in aroma and flavour provided by switching up your yeast. We brewed up a wort with a light caramel note and some toasty biscuit flavour, and hopped it with Amarillo and Centennial for a citrusy bitterness. Everything else is down to the yeast. Abbey style yeasts add distinctive spicy and fruity notes, and dry out the finished beer.
beer.name: Belgian Trappist
beer.tips: Play around with the fermentation temperature to get the best flavour profile from the individual yeasts.

beer.desc: Our flagship beer that kick started the craft beer revolution. This is James and Martin's original take on an American IPA, subverted with punchy New Zealand hops. Layered with new world hops to create an all-out riot of grapefruit, pineapple and lychee before a spiky, mouth-puckering bitter finish.
food: Spicy carne asada with a pico de gallo sauce
Shredded chicken tacos with a mango chilli lime salsa
Cheesecake with a passion fruit swirl sauce
beer.name: Punk IPA 2007 - 2010
beer.tagline: Post Modern Classic. Spiky. Tropical. Hoppy.
beer.tips: While it may surprise you, this version of Punk IPA isn't dry hopped but still packs a punch! To make the best of the aroma hops make sure they are fully submerged and add them just before knock out for an intense hop hit.

beer.desc: A 4.5% decadent scotch ale brewed with Scottish heather honey. A robust malty beer packed with flavour, at a strength you can drink all (Christmas) day long. Santa Paws is our antidote to the chaos of the festive season. All the flavours of Christmas pudding in liquid form.
beer.name: Santa Paws
beer.tips: The addition of Weyermann Beech Smoked malt creates a beer with a delicate smoke character.

beer.desc: This tentacled terminator packs a punch - ten punches to be precise. Each hop addition adds to the intense layers of depth in this red rye IPA. Toasty caramel & cinder toffee from crystal malts, cacao richness from intensely roasted malt and the spiciness of rye. Zesty pithiness from Citra and the robust resin of Chinook. This small batch exclusive brew is up-front intensity matched with twisted complexity. The can features awesome custom art from Joe Wilson.
food: Rocket and mozzarella salad with a cracked pepper dressing
Fried halibut with sweet potato fritters
beer.name: Albino Squid Assasin
beer.tips: 20% specialty malts in this grist can create problems in the run off. Be careful not to pull the bed down onto the plates.

beer.desc: In protest against the potential withdrawal of the USA from the Paris agreement, we brewed a saison (which ferments at high temperatures) with melted ice caps (glacier water) and cloudberries (an Arctic berry).
food: Oysters With a Chilli And Dill Sauce
beer.name: Make Earth Great Again
beer.tips: So your homebrew shop of choice may not stock all the ingredients here! You can buy cloudberry jam and add that instead. The pectin in the jam is not ideal and will form a haze but that can be forgiven in a saison.

beer.desc: This limited edition American Barley Wine was brewed in collaboration with 3 Floyds Brewery. This beer had all the warm, boozy and smoky aspects of an Islay Scotch whisky with the sweet malt and devastatingly bitter attributes of a barley wine. Peat smoke features prominently, backed up with a complex fruity hop profile.
beer.name: Bitch Please (w/ 3 Floyds)
beer.tips: To add to the smoky nature of this Barley Wine, source some smoked wood or whisky casks to age the beer in.

beer.desc: A Vermont IPA with fruit and milk sugars added - recreating fruity milkshake character in an IPA.
food: Thai sweet potato and carrot soup
beer.name: East Of Vermont
beer.tips: If you use mango pulp, extend the time that you whirlpool to let it settle out. Trying to clean mango pulp out of your heat exchanger or cooling coil is not a fun ending to a brewday.

beer.desc: Think banoffee pie; loads of creamy sweet banana, and sticky warm toffee. This beer is super complex, and one for the sweet-toothed!
beer.name: AB:14
beer.tips: Boil for even longer to get more caramelised flavours in the beer.

beer.desc: A fusion of caramel malt flavours and punchy New Zealand hops. A session beer you can get your teeth into.
food: Sharp cheddar cheese and onion/ raisin chutney
beer.name: Alpha Dog
beer.tips: Crush the malt as close to brewing time as possible. The fresher the malt, the more intense caramel flavours will be released in the wort.

beer.desc: A decadent, robust and encapsulating Imperial Ale. A rollercoaster of devilish berries, smooth vanilla, toasted marshmallow and wine gums; caramel malt balanced with moderate bitterness and a roasty edge.
beer.name: AB:10
beer.tagline: Imperial Brown Ale Aged In Spanish Red Wine Barrels.
beer.tips: Be careful of sticking the run-off. There are a lot of specialty malts in this mash that can prove problematic if pulled onto the run-off plates.

beer.desc: A new 7.4% ABV East Coast IPA, King of Eights is one of the core Fanzine beers, and will feature evolving editions as part of our new subscription model.
beer.name: King of Eights
beer.tips: Pectin powder can easily be sourced and is an easy alternative for a homebrewer to produce murky beer if you don’t have access to a low flocculating yeast.

beer.desc: The International Arms Race was a new type of battle collaboration between hardcore American craft brewery Flying Dog and BrewDog. Both breweries attempted to brew an IPA with absolutely no hops.
food: Light vegetable and herb soup with toasted rye bread
Earl Grey ice cream with a lavender sauce
beer.name: International Arms Race (w/ Flying Dog)
beer.tips: Allow the bay leaves to steep in the boil for extra time to extract some bitterness. The bitterness is really important to bring balance to an otherwise sweet beer.

beer.desc: Vanilla pods and toasted oak chips add a rounded character to this massive Russian Imperial Stout, brewed with a hefty malt bill, cacao nibs and coffee beans. Dark malts combine with Cascade to add a punchy bitterness, strong enough to offset the big chocolate sweetness.
food: Espresso crusted venison with a dark cherry jus
beer.name: Cocoa Psycho
beer.tagline: Russian Imperial Stout. Rich. Decadent. Mocha.
beer.tips: Put coffee beans and cocoa nibs in a cheese cloth and dip in wort like a tea bag. Do multiple small additions for short lengths of time – the longer you leave them in the more heavy oils will be extracted.

beer.desc: A decadent, robust and encapsulating Imperial Ale. A rollercoaster of devilish berries, smooth vanilla, toasted marshmallow and wine gums; caramel malt balanced with moderate bitterness and a roasty edge.
beer.name: AB:10
beer.tagline: Imperial Brown Ale Aged In Spanish Red Wine Barrels.
beer.tips: Be careful of sticking the run-off. There are a lot of specialty malts in this mash that can prove problematic if pulled onto the run-off plates.

Poor Bramling Cross normally gets lost in a woeful stream of conformist brown ales made by sleepy cask ale brewers. But not anymore. beer.name: Bramling X
beer.tips: Getting good Bramling Cross is key. Most English hops are in leaf form (not pelletised), so getting fresh hops close to harvest (September) will give this beer the right amount of dark berry intensity.

beer.desc: Pineapple, citrus and papaya; single-hopped with Simcoe, Hoppy Christmas is an anti-festive IPA, redolent with summery flavours. Small caramel malt additions provide a touch of malt complexity. Simcoe, arguably our favourite hop, carries this beer - pine, tropical fruit and bitterness are its specialities.
beer.name: Hoppy Christmas
beer.tips: Get the freshest Simcoe for the best profile.

beer.desc: Good things come to those who wait. This smooth and roasty oatmeal milk stout won our 2015 Prototype Challenge at a canter. Roasty coffee and chocolate lead to a decadent, full-bodied richness of near uncharted depths with a velvet mouthfeel from the addition of oatmeal and a touch of wheat. This is complemented at every turn by the Magnum and Sorachi Ace hops, with the latter bringing an intensity of smooth vanilla and dark berry fruit on the long, rewarding finish.
beer.name: Jet Black Heart
beer.tagline: Oatmeal Milk Stout. Dark. Roasty. Velvety.
beer.tips: There's a lot of speciality malt in the mash. Make sure you take the run off nice and steady – increase the flow too much and pull in the bed at your peril.

beer.desc: 2015 IPA is Dead Series. Supremely floral, this hugely under-rated hop is related to Galaxy and was first cultivated in the Australian state of Victoria. Initially given the same name as a certain Eurolager, their lawyers got involved and the St- prefix was dropped. Ella displays subtle notes of spice, but is fundamentally a truly floral bouquet, redolent of the Southern Hemisphere.
food: Cheddar cheese toastie on dark rye
Lamb samosas with chilli dipping sauce
beer.name: Ella - IPA Is Dead
beer.tips: These beers need to hit FG to really pop. If you're fermentation is struggling, whip up a starter and re-pitch to get some viable yeast in there to finish the job

beer.desc: A draft-only BrewDog bar exclusive; we have experimented with ageing our Vermount IPA for a short time in bourbon and rye barrels, both known for imparting flavour quickly compared to other types of barrel.
beer.name: Hazy Jane Bourbon Barrel Aged
beer.tips: Avoid any oxygen uptake! It will oxidise the delicate hop flavours during the ageing period. Purge your barrel/ageing vessel with CO2 and seal it airtight.

beer.desc: A beer brewed specifically for the British Science Festival, held in Swansea.
beer.name: Science IPA
beer.tips: This beer is all about the balance between the malty backbone of the beer and the fresh hop aroma. The fresher the hops the better.

beer.desc: This Cranachan Imperial Stout was inspired by the famous Scottish dessert, and brewed with a mountain of dark malts, loads of oats, Scottish heather honey and local raspberries. The beer was then transferred to oak casks to mature for 6 months.
food: Aged cheddar with honey and raspberry chutney
Rich beef stew with winter vegetables and a dash of honey
beer.name: AB:09
beer.tips: Lactose - or milk sugar - is un-fermentable. It adds a creamy mouthfeel to the beer. Experiment by using different types of honey for altered flavour profiles.

beer.desc: Hoppy citrus and tropical fruit Saison.
beer.name: Hoppy Saison - B-Sides
beer.tips: The stepped mash really makes the most out the raw ingredients. If you can't achieve this mash for 60mins at 65°C.

beer.desc: Democratically voted on by you and the BrewDog beer community. A wonderfully burnt toast malt backbone, loaded with American Hops for floral, citrus flavours and warm boozy vanilla and toasted oak.
beer.name: #Mashtag 2015
beer.tips: Steep the oak chips and vanilla in separate bags in the cold conditioning phase. Taste every 2 - 3 days and as soon as profile is desirable they can be removed easily.

beer.desc: Pounding a triple payload of the biggest North American hops humanity has devised, braced by a backbone of caramel malt, this beer is deep, astringent and resinous, pushing to the extremes of lupulin thresholds. There’s nothing inscrutable going on; no mystery in the backstory. It doesn’t seek to be understood. A beer incapable of empathy; only hop overload.
food: Spicy wings with blue cheese dip
Pan seared scallops with a chilli sauce
beer.name: Hardcore IPA
beer.tagline: Explicit Imperial Ale. Citrusy. Resinous. Intense.
beer.tips: There are so much hops in this beer it may break your gear! Watch out for the end of casting (or knockout for our American brethern), you don’t want to pull too much trub into the fermenter.

beer.desc: Japanese citrus fruit intensifies the sour nature of this German classic.
beer.name: Berliner Weisse With Yuzu - B-Sides
beer.tips: Clean everything twice. All you want is the clean sourness of lactobacillus.

beer.desc: A hark back to the origins of Saison; slight spice and earthy notes with highlights of lemon and pepper make a beer that could quench the thirst of any seasonal worker.
beer.name: Baby Saison - B-Sides
beer.tips: Ferment between 21 and 24°C to get this saison as dry as possible.

beer.desc: We asked the public to tell us the one beer we should brew again, from our entire back catalogue. They chose well. Cloudberries team up with pan-global hops for an all out fruit riot against a caramel malt base.
beer.name: Hello My Name Is Ingrid 2016
beer.tips: Add the cloudberries to your beer when racking the beer after primary fermentation. Grind them into a paste to allow maximum flavour extraction.

beer.desc: In protest against the potential withdrawal of the USA from the Paris agreement, we brewed a saison (which ferments at high temperatures) with melted ice caps (glacier water) and cloudberries (an Arctic berry).
food: Oysters With a Chilli And Dill Sauce
beer.name: Make Earth Great Again
beer.tips: So your homebrew shop of choice may not stock all the ingredients here! You can buy cloudberry jam and add that instead. The pectin in the jam is not ideal and will form a haze but that can be forgiven in a saison.

beer.desc: Our Q4 Seasonal is a red rye IPA. This twist on an American IPA involves a more complex malt base, with the careful addition of rye - a grain known for its trickiness when brewing with anything above a tiny percentage.
food: Barbeque and Mustard Beef on Rye Bread
beer.name: Slot Machine
beer.tips: Rye can cause run off problems. Try to reach a temperature of 78 degrees Celsius if possible, and sparge at the same temperature.

beer.desc: Like IPA historically would have been. Part of this beer was aged on a fishing boat in an oak cask and released as "Atlantic IPA".
beer.name: Atlantic IPA Ale
beer.tips: Ensure you aerate the wort to get a nice clean fermentation and really get the best out of the UK hops.

beer.desc: Democratically voted on by you and the BrewDog beer community. A wonderfully burnt toast malt backbone, loaded with American Hops for floral, citrus flavours and warm boozy vanilla and toasted oak.
beer.name: #Mashtag 2015
beer.tips: Steep the oak chips and vanilla in separate bags in the cold conditioning phase. Taste every 2 - 3 days and as soon as profile is desirable they can be removed easily.

beer.desc: We're turning Hallowe’en inside out and upside down. Pumpkin King is not your usual unctuous, cloyingly sweet Hallowe’en pumpkin ale. Sure, there’s a huge heady hit of pungent spice on the nose, but it’s followed with bright and zesty citrus flavours, and a light mouthfeel. Spicy and sweet autumnal favourites like toasted marshmallow and toffee apple are just some of the complex notes you’ll find in our twisted take on a pumpkin ale, which weighs in at 5.4% ABV.
food: Creamy maple syrup and bacon soup
Chunky chicken and vegetable spiced stew
beer.name: Pumpkin King
beer.tips: Experiment with the spice addition to find the correct balance to suit your taste. FYI star anise is a very strong flavour.

beer.desc: No Label is a postmodern, postgender non-binary brew; the world’s first beer made with transgender hops. Brewed with whole hop bines that have spontaneously changed from female to male, no label goes its own way. No Label balances a light, biscuity dryness from the malt base with delicate hints of fruity esters gifted by the fermentation. Finally, dry- hopping adds a layer of new world tropical & pine flavours that add a unique twist to this classic Kölsch style beer. All profits from the sales of this beer were donated to LGBTQI+ events organisers Queerest of the Queer.
food: Strawberry and basil salad with feta
beer.name: No Label
beer.tips: Dry hop using a muslin bag in order to give you the best chance at getting the signature Kölsch clarity.

beer.desc: This straight-up US style pale ale uses some of our favourite hops against a toasty malt base. We brewed this with Sir Tom Hunter at our Fraserburgh brewery - to add a charitable element to your own version, feel free to share this citrusy pale ale with your friends. Or don't, it's your choice.
food: Barbecue corn and steak fajita seasoned wrap
beer.name: Hunter Foundation Pale Ale
beer.tips: To dry the beer out, mash at a slightly lower temp (62° - 63°C), this will increase the ratio of fermentable sugars in the beer.

beer.desc: Our anniversary stout was based on AB:04, one of our most sought after beers ever. This beer is slightly different each year, with subtle variations coming into play purely down to environmental and fermentation factors. What doesn't change is the rich dark chocolate, bitter coffee and chili warmth of this monumental stout.
beer.name: Dog A
beer.tagline: Cacao, Coffee, Chili Imperial Anniversary Stout.
beer.tips: Be really careful when mashing, as this amount of malt can get tough to sparge! Add honey into the boil, and naga chili and vanilla in maturation (soak them in some neutral spirit to sanitise)

beer.desc: This Cranachan Imperial Stout was inspired by the famous Scottish dessert, and brewed with a mountain of dark malts, loads of oats, Scottish heather honey and local raspberries. The beer was then transferred to oak casks to mature for 6 months.
food: Aged cheddar with honey and raspberry chutney
Rich beef stew with winter vegetables and a dash of honey
beer.name: AB:09
beer.tips: Lactose - or milk sugar - is un-fermentable. It adds a creamy mouthfeel to the beer. Experiment by using different types of honey for altered flavour profiles.

beer.desc: After the success of the first version of Sidewalk Shark (a BrewDog bar exclusive), we decided to brew a second version, this time infused with tropical flavours of pineapple, coconut and lime.
food: Baked Tilapia With Lemon and Cream Sauce
beer.name: Pina Colada Sidewalk
beer.tips: Be careful with your salt additions. A very light saltiness aids the refreshing character. It should not overpower or drive you to seek another different beer to refresh your palate.

beer.desc: Brewed for the Tate Modern’s 10th Anniversary. A saison style beer brewed with ginger and orange peel. Very limited batch of 4000 cork and caged bottles with a silk screened label designed by Johanna Basford. Only available at the Tate Modern.
beer.name: TM10
beer.tips: For a fresh and fiery hit, put some ginger into the cold conditioning phase as well.

beer.desc: The levels of hops vary throughout the range. We love hops, so all four beers are big, bitter badasses, but by tweaking the amount of each hop used later in the boil and during dry- hopping, we can balance the malty backbone with some unexpected flavours. Simcoe is used in the whirlpool for all four beers, and yet still lends different characters to each.
food: Roast chicken with vegetables and wild rice
Fresh pico de gallo with corn tortilla
beer.name: Pale - Russian Doll
beer.tips: Create balance through experimentation with the hop amounts and malt backbone.

beer.desc: Brewed exclusively for the Italian market, this Hello My Name brew features a twist of flavours inspired by Italy.
beer.name: Hello My Name Is Sofia
beer.tips: Keep an eye on your pH as you are adding your lemon juice. Yeast can tolerate low pH conditions but the length of fermentation may take longer than normal.

beer.desc: Brewing a full flavoured craft beer at 0.5% is no easy task. Packed with loads of Centennial, Amarillo, Columbus, Cascade and Simcoe hops, dry hopped to the brink and back and sitting at 55 IBUs, Nanny State is a force to be reckoned with. With a backbone of 8 different specialty malts, Nanny State will tantalise your taste buds and leave you yearning for more.
beer.name: Nanny State
beer.tips: Get hops in every stage of the brewing process - mash, run off boil and flame off. There's not too much malt body, so the more hops the better.

beer.desc: Zeitgeist is an idiosyncratic alternative black lager. Its inspiration is found more than 200 years ago. Zeitgeist takes an age old classic, a forgotten masterpiece, and gives it relevance and an avant-garde edge.
food: Pork dumplings with rich soy sauce
Cinnamon carrot cake with creamy cheese frosting
beer.name: Zeitgeist
beer.tips: Inspect the colour of the wort during boiling. If it is not quite dark enough, extend the boil by 10 - 15 mins and check again. The wort will darken during the boiling process.

beer.desc: Pineapple, citrus and papaya; single-hopped with Simcoe, Hoppy Christmas is an anti-festive IPA, redolent with summery flavours. Small caramel malt additions provide a touch of malt complexity. Simcoe, arguably our favourite hop, carries this beer - pine, tropical fruit and bitterness are its specialities.
beer.name: Hoppy Christmas
beer.tips: Get the freshest Simcoe for the best profile.

beer.desc: With all the rich tropical flavour you'd expect from Australia's Galaxy, this beer backs up a strong citrus aroma and flavour with a mellow undercurrent of passion fruit and mango. Zingy and sweet but not too sweet, Galaxy has a soft and inviting fruity hop character.
food: Spicy green chilli and lemongrass chicken thai curry
beer.name: Galaxy
beer.tips: Use fresh Galaxy for the best flavour profile.

beer.desc: Low ABV, high flavour, this beer was brewed to show that a beer can have all the flavour without the drunken affects. Also this beer is one of BrewDog's original brews that made a rare appearance in cask. Spicy, malty biscuit and super drinkable.
beer.name: Edge
beer.tips: Don’t overcook the mash - 75 minutes only at 65°C to get the right amount of fermentable sugars. Leave it too long and the beer ends up really watery and unpleasant.

beer.desc: Vote Sepp is a single hop wheat beer brewed to a session strength, with hibiscus flower, which gives it an impressively vibrant shade of pink. What Vote Sepp lacks in complexity, it more than makes up for in a perfect balance of tartness, bitterness and body.
food: Caprese salad (mozzarella, tomato, basil, black pepper and sea salt)
beer.name: Vote Sepp
beer.tips: Load hibiscus in the hot wort in a tea bag.

beer.desc: Brewed with our Equity Punks this rich, smooth stout is brewed with a blend of six malts, resulting in a welcoming, resonant black beer. From start to finish it carries an intense roastiness reminiscent of dark chocolate intertwined with a delicate hint of coconut and caramel.
food: Butternut squash soup with toasted almonds
beer.name: Bounty Hunter - Shareholder Brew
beer.tips: Lightly toast the coconut chips to allow better interaction with the hot wort.

beer.desc: Out of order and stability comes the rush of the pack. Berry and caramel riding alongside marmalade and chocolate. Spice and toast jostle with lychee and biscuit. The needle flicks to all points of the compass. It drives you towards the horizon, towards the vanishing point. And it keeps going...
food: Cheddar cheese melt on crisp rye toast
beer.name: 5am Saint
beer.tips: Go easy on the crystal and dark crystal malt. Too much will skew the flavour profile away from lychees and citrus towards dried fruit.

beer.desc: Brewed with over ten different types of malt, and blended together with Scottish heather honey, it is a pantheon to the gods of intricacy and nuance; a beer that celebratesa confluence of ideas. Complex, indulgent and encapsulating, Dogma gives more than a cursory nod to history, to make you ponder the very nature of beer itself.
food: Mature cheddar with red onion chutney
beer.name: Dogma
beer.tagline: Revamped Wee Heavy. Luscious. Malty. Fruity.
beer.tips: There's a lot of specialty malt in the mash. Make sure you take the run off nice and steady – increase the flow too much and pull in the bed at your peril.

beer.desc: Brewed to a concept voted on at Craft Beer Rising, this one-off beer is an experimental brew which emulates the flavour of lemon meringue pie.
beer.name: Small Batch: Lemon Meringue Pie
beer.tips: Dextrin Malt adds sugars to your wort that the yeast are unable to ferment. If you want a sweetness remaining in your beer, add a little of this but not too much!!!

beer.desc: A triple whammy of coffee from HasBean gives our 17th Abstrakt concept beer an intense and roasty, dark mocha character. We brewed with espresso in the mash, cafetiere in the boil, and whole roast beans in the whirlpool and the fermenter.
beer.name: AB:17
beer.tips: Use freshly ground coffee for the best aromatic hit.

beer.desc: Jack Hammer has been single handedly ripping it up for quite some time. Now, the definitive bitter and twisted IPA, has spawned four Hammer Head off-springs. Black Hammer is the second of our hyped up hybrid IPAs. A black hearted beast, that takes no prisoners. American hops and dark malt combine to make mischief. Grapefruit and coffee collide in sensory overload – a wake-up call for other IPA’s. Molten waves of pithy grapefruit build and finally ebb to the roasty bitter onslaught. Stand  firm and wield the Black Hammer with care. Stare into the black abyss and succumb to the dark-side.
food: Buffalo wings with blue cheese dip
beer.name: Black Hammer
beer.tagline: Our Ruthless IPA With A Dark Malt Twist.
beer.tips: You may have to leave this beer on dry hops for slightly longer than usual to let the flavours balance.

beer.desc: A draft-only BrewDog bar exclusive; we have experimented with ageing our Vermount IPA for a short time in bourbon and rye barrels, both known for imparting flavour quickly compared to other types of barrel.
food: Orange and carrot cake with orange cream cheese icing
beer.name: Hazy Jane Rye Barrel Aged
beer.tips: Avoid any oxygen uptake! It will oxidise the delicate hop flavours during the ageing period. Purge your barrel/ageing vessel with CO2 and seal it airtight.

beer.desc: The brainchild of our small batch brewer, George Woods. A dangerously drinkable milk sugar- infused Scotch Ale.
food: Roasted garlic and chilli infused camembert cheese
beer.name: Misspent Youth
beer.tips: Lots of malt in this one. Mash-in in stages, and spread the pale ale malt throughout the mash to provide stability. If the mash starts to sink, stop, wait a few minutes while mixing, then start again.

beer.desc: A new 5% ABV Vienna Lager, that features in Fanzine, our new subscription model.
beer.name: Interstate Vienna Lager.
beer.tips: Instead of using Pilsner, try to substitute this out for more Vienna malt. This is more traditional but you should calculate your diastatic power for your new mash. Ideally it should be a minimum of 30 to 50 Lintner.

beer.desc: A Double IPA with cloudberries added to the conditioning tank. One thing is certain – this Swedish inspired Double IPA is not as innocent as she first appears. A seductive body of rich malts and a buxom amount of Citra, Nelson Sauvin and Bramling Cross hops have been added to fresh Scandinavian cloudberries to deliver this beer’s tart finish.
food: Crayfish with a chilli, coriander infused butter dip
Cardamom cake with powder sugar and cloudberry jam
beer.name: Hello My Name Is Ingrid
beer.tips: Add the cloudberries to your beer when racking the beer after primary fermentation. Grind them into a paste to allow maximum flavour extraction.

beer.desc: A 4.7% German Pils with light, biscuit and toasty malt character, upon which is built a hop bitterness that provides complexity and a long, dry finish.
beer.name: Kingpin
beer.tips: Keep an eye on your fermentation temperature to ensure you get the crisp notes that are the hallmark of a good pilsner.

beer.desc: Brewed with over ten different types of malt, and blended together with Scottish heather honey, it is a pantheon to the gods of intricacy and nuance; a beer that celebratesa confluence of ideas. Complex, indulgent and encapsulating, Dogma gives more than a cursory nod to history, to make you ponder the very nature of beer itself.
food: Mature cheddar with red onion chutney
beer.name: Dogma
beer.tagline: Revamped Wee Heavy. Luscious. Malty. Fruity.
beer.tips: There's a lot of specialty malt in the mash. Make sure you take the run off nice and steady – increase the flow too much and pull in the bed at your peril.

beer.desc: Belgian Imperial Stout aged on toasted coconut and cacao. The Belgian yeast strain introduces a whole new dimension to the Imperial Stout style resulting in a beer that resembles a marshmallow toasted on a smouldering barbeque then smothered in dark chocolate. Massively seductive and encapsulating this blacker than midnight beer pours with coffee brown head so thick you could almost stand on it, and with an epic lacing on your glass.
beer.name: AB:05
beer.tips: Add the coconut and cacao nibs after primary fermentation and let infuse for at least 6 months at a low temperature.

beer.desc: Our crew designed it, and we bottled it just for ourselves! We chose an 8% red ale, mash hopped and first wort hopped with New Zealand origin hops.
beer.name: Crew Brew
beer.tips: Bring a few bottles to your local BrewDog bar when it's done and ask the staff if you got it right, they're the only ones who can tell you for sure! They'll also probably know of other homebrewers and beer enthusiasts nearby that you can link in with to share your experiences and get awesome first hand advice from.

beer.desc: A session IPA brewed with a diverse grain bill, hopped with Simcoe and Amarillo and fermented with saison yeast, for an incredible level of depth in a low ABV beer. Spicy, fruity, complex, refreshing and dry.
food: Spicy Daal with garlic naan bread
beer.name: Magic Stone Dog (w/Magic Rock & Stone Brewing Co.)
beer.tagline: Session Farmhouse IPA - Stone / Magic Rock Collab.
beer.tips: Start the fermentation off at 20 ̊C and allow it to rise as high as 25 ̊C. This will increase the fruity character of the yeast.

beer.desc: The Pacific North West of America is home to the Citra hop. America is not just about cheer leaders, a silly version of football, elastic top jeans and cheeseburgers. They grow remarkable hops and Citra is a killer example of this, embodying all that is good about American hops and then some. Fearfully hard to resist, this beer is loaded with brash citrus, grapefruit, orange, hints of resinous pine and touches of blackcurrant. Devilishly moreish.
food: Shredded chicken tacos with pico de gallo
beer.name: Citra
beer.tips: Another hop to be treated with respect. Too much in the kettle or dry hop will turn the beer into a garlicky disaster.

beer.desc: Santa Paws Scotch ale aged in bourbon barrels - light, dry and toasty, with vanilla, hints of chocolate and ginger biscuit, and a faint spicy hoppiness.
beer.name: Bourbon Baby
beer.tips: Use bourbon-soaked oak chips in secondary to achieve barrel character.

beer.desc: Our flagship beer that kick started the craft beer revolution. This is James and Martin's original take on an American IPA, subverted with punchy New Zealand hops. Layered with new world hops to create an all-out riot of grapefruit, pineapple and lychee before a spiky, mouth-puckering bitter finish.
food: Spicy carne asada with a pico de gallo sauce
Shredded chicken tacos with a mango chilli lime salsa
Cheesecake with a passion fruit swirl sauce
beer.name: Punk IPA 2007 - 2010
beer.tagline: Post Modern Classic. Spiky. Tropical. Hoppy.
beer.tips: While it may surprise you, this version of Punk IPA isn't dry hopped but still packs a punch! To make the best of the aroma hops make sure they are fully submerged and add them just before knock out for an intense hop hit.

beer.desc: An imperial stout brewed with cacao and coffee, AB22 has spent two years in darkness, drawing complex and indulgent flavours from the Speyside whisky casks in which it resided.
beer.name: AB:22
beer.tips: Soak American oak (medium toasted) chips in your favourite Speyside tipple overnight and add them after primary fermentation

beer.desc: BrewDog vs La Pirata. One of a series of collaborations with European craft breweries, aimed at promoting engagement and market growth. Our collab with Spanish brewes La Pirata features a barley wine, inspired by Muscatel.
beer.name: Al Adjore!
beer.tips: Sanitise the oak chips before adding them to the fermenter. Vodka is ideal as it’s a neutral spirit and can be drained off. If you don’t want to affect the ABV, try steaming them.

beer.desc: Brewed for the beer maniacs in Denmark, this Double IPA quivered with kumquat, kiwi and orange pith all held together with a honeycomb malt body.
food: Thick cut salami pieces on tiger bread
Poached pear and blue cheese crumble
beer.name: Hardkogt IPA
beer.tagline: A Special Double IPA For Our Danish Friends.
beer.tips: It’s better to over-pitch your yeast here to ensure the beer ferments out.

beer.desc: Our Unleash the Yeast series was an epic experiment into the differences in aroma and flavour provided by switching up your yeast. We brewed up a wort with a light caramel note and some toasty biscuit flavour, and hopped it with Amarillo and Centennial for a citrusy bitterness. Everything else is down to the yeast. Pilsner yeast ferments with no fruity esters or spicy phenols, although it can add a hint of butterscotch.
food: Spicy cucumber and carrot Thai salad
beer.name: Pilsen Lager
beer.tips: Play around with the fermentation temperature to get the best flavour profile from the individual yeasts.

beer.desc: Dog E is a very special beer. This beer commemorates our 9th year in 2016. This beer originally appeared as AB:04 in 2010, perhaps the most sought after beer we ever brewed. Dog E is a 16.1% Imperial Stout brewed with copious amounts of dark malts, pure cacao and coffee, balanced by the subtle addition of naga chili, and barrel-aged. Perfect for ageing in your cellar, or drinking fresh if you’re lucky enough to get your paws on a bottle.
beer.name: Dog E
beer.tips: With stronger styles (like imperial stouts), feel free to cellar your beer and try a bottle every few months to see how the flavours have developed – often the beer picks up new, incredible flavours.

beer.desc: Deconstructed whisky sour, reconstructed as a beer.
beer.name: Whisky Sour - B-Sides
beer.tips: Lemon poppyseed donuts.

beer.desc: Roasty, dark and complex, Stereo Wolf is a 5.2% ABV Stout brewed with a cacophony of hop-driven fruit and spice. Dark chocolate stalks alongside the resonating bitterness, through to Stereo Wolf’s lingering dry finish. Balancing roasty malt and new world hops at 5.2% ABV is no mean feat, but Stereo Wolf takes it in its stride.
beer.name: Stereo Wolf Stout - Prototype Challenge
beer.tips: Special W is a specialty malt that creates an intense profile of nuts, raisins and caramel. It provides a focal point for the malt base, that the hops can stack against.

beer.desc: Hoppy citrus and tropical fruit Saison.
beer.name: Hoppy Saison - B-Sides
beer.tips: The stepped mash really makes the most out the raw ingredients. If you can't achieve this mash for 60mins at 65°C.

beer.desc: This beer is about pushing the boundaries, it is about taking innovation in beer to a whole new level. Dark and decadent, plum, treacle and roast coffee are amplified beyond any stout you've had before.
beer.name: Tactical Nuclear Penguin
beer.tips: This level of alcohol can be achieved using a domestic freezer. Use a container with a tap close to the bottom so you can run the un-frozen, concentrated beer from under the ice on top. You may have to do this three or four times.

beer.desc: We love hops. We adore and worship their profile ability to transform beer. You could say that we have a terminal addiction. To celebrate this fetish we’re heroing our favourites in single hopped limited releases. No also starring, no extras, no compromise. The Hop is the Hero. A biscuity malty backbone builds to resinous pine with explosive citrus notes, culminating in a mango hit and a long bitter finish. This is pure Hop fusion, imploding with sensory overload. Our Ace in the hole, devastatingly singular, deliciously bitter. Serving up an Ace each and every time.
beer.name: Ace Of Simcoe
beer.tips: Try adding a small portion of the hops to the kettle before you boil, as first wort hops.

beer.desc: A dark and decadent beer brewed with coconut, vanilla, cacao.
beer.name: Self Assembly Pope
beer.tips: Don't be shy with the roasted coconut, it's a delicate flavour compared to the rest of the beer, so go nuts! If it grows wild near you, go grab some Gorse and chuck it in too for a local natural boost to the coconut flavours.

beer.desc: BrewDog vs Brlo. One of a series of collaborations with European craft breweries, aimed at promoting engagement and market growth. Our German collaboration is with BRLO, and the beer is a dry- hopped Maibock; a new world take on a strong pale lager.
beer.name: SOS! (May Day!)
beer.tips: Traditional German brewing is awesome and deserving of respect. If you brew this during spring time, call it a Maibock, any other time of the year and it should be called an Helles Bock.

beer.desc: A Pilot Brew "Sunshine on Rye" uses loads of spicy malt and coriander to play nice with an inhuman amount of hops!
beer.name: Sunshine On Rye - B-Sides
beer.tips: Indian coriander accentuates the citrus character from the hops. Use fresh spices to really accentuate this relationship.

beer.desc: Our crew designed it, and we bottled it just for ourselves! We chose an 8% red ale, mash hopped and first wort hopped with New Zealand origin hops.
beer.name: Crew Brew
beer.tips: Bring a few bottles to your local BrewDog bar when it's done and ask the staff if you got it right, they're the only ones who can tell you for sure! They'll also probably know of other homebrewers and beer enthusiasts nearby that you can link in with to share your experiences and get awesome first hand advice from.

beer.desc: An utterly indulgent, smooth as hell Stout. With opulent flavours of chocolate milkshake, roasty espresso coffee, and mellow vanilla, this beer has a full-bodied and creamy mouthfeel.
beer.name: Small Batch: Nitro Breakfast Stout
beer.tips: * Not a suitable replacement for an actual breakfast. Nitroing at home is, well, not impossible but unlikely. Luckily this beer tastes great when lightly carbonated too! Be prepared for a slow runoff and don’t skimp on the cacao!

beer.desc: BrewDog vs. Weihenstephan India Pale Weizen kicked off a new direction for our collaborations. We took a simple concept (by our standards) and teamed up with the oldest brewery in the world to brew a mash-up beer using the signature styles of both breweries. India Pale Weizen has classic base hefeweizen aromas and flavours of banana, clove and bubblegum, with a distinctive haziness. Layered on top of this is a tapestry of US citrus hop character. India Pale Weizen is a perfect symbiosis of traditional and modern brewing.
food: Waffles with caramelised apple and powdered sugar
beer.name: India Pale Weizen (w/ Weihenstephan)
beer.tips: Let the fermentation temperature creep up a couple of degrees higher than normal to create the characteristic banana and bubblegum aromas.

beer.desc: Our Blitz series sees us brew up low abv, super tart Berliner Weisse, and generally infuse them with bags of sour fruit flavour – but this batch uses gin botanicals instead.
beer.name: Gin Blitz
beer.tips: Crack open/mash up the Juniper berries to get the most flavour and aroma from them.

beer.desc: Our California style West Coast IPA has light toffee and caramel notes layered on biscuit malt, supporting a huge, fresh citrus aroma, with lemongrass, lime zest, grapefruit peel, alongside some tropical notes, courtesy of some heavy-hitting US hops.
beer.name: Dead Pony Club
beer.tagline: West Coast Kicks. Citrusy. Zesty. Bright.
beer.tips: It may be tempting to throw extra (extra) hops at Dead Pony Club, but try adding a little at a time to consecutive brews rather than cramming in loads extra on your first time.

beer.desc: Our Unleash the Yeast series was an epic experiment into the differences in aroma and flavour provided by switching up your yeast. We brewed up a wort with a light caramel note and some toasty biscuit flavour, and hopped it with Amarillo and Centennial for a citrusy bitterness. Everything else is down to the yeast. American Ale used a clean fermenting strain which provides some faint fruity notes.
beer.name: American Ale
beer.tips: Play around with the fermentation temperature to get the best flavour profile from the individual yeasts.

beer.desc: Brewed exclusively for the Dutch market, this Hello My Name brew features a twist of flavour inspired by the Netherlands.
beer.name: Hello My Name Is Lieke
beer.tips: The Seville Orange is a bitter orange, so adjust your bittering hop addition down to account for the fact that there will be a contribution from them.

beer.desc: A cheeky play with a new hop on the pilot kit. Expect notes of redcurrant, melon and citrus. An intriguing possibility for the future.
food: Jalapeño poppers with blue cheese dip
Carrot cake with cream cheese frosting
beer.name: Single Hop Enigma IPA - B-Sides
beer.tips: Enigma has a very high alpha acid so be careful not to over do the bittering hops.

beer.desc: A luscious blend of peach, blood orange and banana to make a suitably refreshing beverage that happily straddles the Atlantic.
food: Fish corn tacos with pomegranate salsa
beer.name: American Wheat
beer.tips: Using a starter to get your yeast as vibrant and healthy as possible will make all the difference here.

beer.desc: A deliciously robust, black malted beer with a decadent dark, dry cocoa flavour that provides an enticing backdrop to the Cascade hops.
beer.name: Movember
beer.tips: If you can’t find really fresh cascade, substitute it for Amarillo or Ahtanum.

beer.desc: Piney, citrusy and resinous with herbal notes, Vic Secret is dual-purpose (flavour & bitterness) perfect for brewing up a single hop IPA.
food: Gorgonzola and rye nut bread with smoked honey ham
beer.name: Vic Secret
beer.tips: You can always add more hops, but it is difficult to take them away. Carry out multiple additions of the hops during dry hopping to achieve the best profile.

beer.desc: Pineapple, citrus and papaya; single-hopped with Simcoe, Hoppy Christmas is an anti-festive IPA, redolent with summery flavours. Small caramel malt additions provide a touch of malt complexity. Simcoe, arguably our favourite hop, carries this beer - pine, tropical fruit and bitterness are its specialities.
beer.name: Hoppy Christmas
beer.tips: Get the freshest Simcoe for the best profile.

beer.desc: Think bakewell tart with Christmas spices.
food: Wild rice salad with wild mushrooms
beer.name: Spiced Cherry Sour - B-Sides
beer.tips: In the boil: cinnamon, star anise, clove, guinea pepper. After fermentation add: raspberry puree, cherry concentrate, bitter almond extract, American oak chips and Tahitian vanilla beans.

beer.desc: A Vermont style IPA, with low background bitterness, loaded with juicy fruit character. Pine, stonefruit, mango, light resin and hints of lime peel - this juicy IPA is low in bitterness, full-bodied and smooth, enhancing the soft ripe fruit flavours.
beer.name: Hazy Jane
beer.tips: This beer is supposed to be very cloudy. Don’t be shy to get a good bit of the hot break into the fermenter.

beer.desc: The Pacific North West of America is home to the Citra hop. America is not just about cheer leaders, a silly version of football, elastic top jeans and cheeseburgers. They grow remarkable hops and Citra is a killer example of this, embodying all that is good about American hops and then some. Fearfully hard to resist, this beer is loaded with brash citrus, grapefruit, orange, hints of resinous pine and touches of blackcurrant. Devilishly moreish.
food: Shredded chicken tacos with pico de gallo
beer.name: Citra
beer.tips: Another hop to be treated with respect. Too much in the kettle or dry hop will turn the beer into a garlicky disaster.

beer.desc: A forgotten gem in the deepest, darkest corner of the warehouse. Aged in a Lowland whisky cask resulting in decadent chocolate, toasted vanilla, indulgent spiced fruit, a mesmerizingly hypnotic mouthfeel and new layers that emerge on every sip.
beer.name: Tokyo Rising Sun - Lowland
beer.tips: Leave on wood for as long as you dare. If possible forget about it for four years.

beer.desc: This French white wine barrel aged Imperial Saison has a plethora of intertwining flavours. Huge aromas of peach, syrup, tangerine, sherry, toffee and raisin, followed by a dynamic bracing acidity.
beer.name: Everday Anarchy
beer.tagline: White Wine Barrel-Aged Imperial Red Saison.
beer.tips: The honey addition will help to dry out the beer, as the saison yeast will continue to ferment long after most ale yeast.

beer.desc: Off-Duty Alien is a citrus IPA, brewed with blood orange and grapefruit to enhance the citurs characteristics of the hops.
beer.name: Off-Duty Alien
beer.tips: Adding the orange and grapefruit peels to the mash gently extracts the essential oils from the peel but leaves the bitter pith behind in the spent grain.

beer.desc: An English Barley Wine brewed with coffee and milk, with rich toasty & caramel flavours. To complete the tiramisu effect, we’ve blended this with a 3 year rum cask aged Imperial Stout.
beer.name: AB:20
beer.tips: Use only very dry coffee beans like Sumatran ones. This way your head retention will not be affected by the oils from the beans.

beer.desc: Our Prototype Challenge sees us pit three new trial beers against each other. This Double IPA is packed with a blend of our favourite American hops and has a huge dry- hop aroma.
food: Hot Wings And Blue Cheese Dip
Sticky Toffee Pudding And Salted Caramel Ice Cream
beer.name: Prototype Double IPA
beer.tips: The hopping rate should leave a light residual haze in your beer after maturation. Don’t worry, this comes from the hop compounds, haze is taste.

beer.desc: An avalanche of cross-continental hop varieties give this porter a complex spicy, resinous and citrusy aroma, with a huge malt bill providing a complex roasty counterpoint. Digging deeper into the flavour draws out cinder toffee, bitter chocolate and hints of woodsmoke.
beer.name: Libertine Porter
beer.tips: Mash in at a higher temperature to leave more unfermentable sugars in the wort. This gives the beer a sweeter porter profile.

beer.desc: This is East Kent Goldings re- invented and re-imagined and shows just what can be done with English hops if you use enough of them. In this amped up Goldings reincarnation expect to be slammed with floral lavender, a fruity riot of blackberries and spiced pears, bubblegum, plums and the illusion of thyme.
beer.name: Goldings - IPA Is Dead
beer.tips: Take a read through each year’s hop harvest that is available. Some years are better than others.

beer.desc: A draft-only BrewDog bar exclusive; we have experimented with ageing our Vermount IPA for a short time in bourbon and rye barrels, both known for imparting flavour quickly compared to other types of barrel.
food: Orange and carrot cake with orange cream cheese icing
beer.name: Hazy Jane Rye Barrel Aged
beer.tips: Avoid any oxygen uptake! It will oxidise the delicate hop flavours during the ageing period. Purge your barrel/ageing vessel with CO2 and seal it airtight.

beer.desc: The Overlord of mango and chili IPA’s packs a fruity punch and then some. Pours a slightly hazy orange. A tropical fruit assault on the nose, with mango, pineapple, apricots and citrus. Hints of chili and sweet malts follow. Fruit dissipates to a chili kick, not hot but definitely there, followed by a long bitter finish. All hail to the hot tempered sweet toothed Lord.
beer.name: Neon Overlord
beer.tips: This fermentation is going to be wild. Use a blow off rather than an airlock to cope with the extra activity.

beer.desc: Scottish chocolate breakfast Stout - brewed with Brazilian Sertão coffee, Venezuelan cacao and (for the Scottish element) oatmeal. Smooth, chocolately and rich, with a honeycomb mouthfeel and a rich red berry coffee character. Brewed with our beer blogger friends from The Beer Cast and Hopzine.
beer.name: Dead Metaphor
beer.tips: Steep the cocoa nibs and chocolate in the hot wort for a short period for the best extraction of flavour compounds.

beer.desc: AB:11 is an Imperial Black Barley Wine brewed with ginger, black raspberries and chipotle peppers. A 12.8% rollercoaster of ginger zestiness and chipotle smokiness, all bound together with dark berry tartness and the decadent residual body of a Black Barley Wine.
food: Steak taquitos with spicy mole sauce
Herb roasted duck with a fruit sauce
Dark chocolate and chilli flourless cake
beer.name: AB:11
beer.tagline: Black Barley Wine With Ginger, Raspberries, Chipotle Peppers.
beer.tips: Use chipotle morito chillies to add a subtle level of smoky character to the beer.

beer.desc: A Vermont style IPA, with low background bitterness, loaded with juicy fruit character. Pine, stonefruit, mango, light resin and hints of lime peel - this juicy IPA is low in bitterness, full-bodied and smooth, enhancing the soft ripe fruit flavours.
beer.name: Hazy Jane
beer.tips: This beer is supposed to be very cloudy. Don’t be shy to get a good bit of the hot break into the fermenter.

beer.desc: Our first 2018 Wildcard brew, Kamikaze Knitting Club is a one-off brew. A maple stout, Kamikaze combines dark malts with a classic Canadian export, adding to the warming malty and smokey character.
beer.name: Kamikaze Knitting Club
beer.tips: Try experimenting with fenugreek seeds which give off a maple syrup like flavour.

beer.desc: A rich, nutty Brown Ale with a deep, rich malt profile, hopped with a range of citrusy and spicy US varieties. Mellow yet endlessly complex, with enough chocolate and fruit character to balance the bitterness, and a soft oaky roundness.
beer.name: #Mashtag 2013
beer.tips: Add the hazelnuts and oak chips during the cold conditioning phase.

beer.desc: A rich, nutty Brown Ale with a deep, rich malt profile, hopped with a range of citrusy and spicy US varieties. Mellow yet endlessly complex, with enough chocolate and fruit character to balance the bitterness, and a soft oaky roundness.
beer.name: #Mashtag 2013
beer.tips: Add the hazelnuts and oak chips during the cold conditioning phase.

beer.desc: A triple whammy of coffee from HasBean gives our 17th Abstrakt concept beer an intense and roasty, dark mocha character. We brewed with espresso in the mash, cafetiere in the boil, and whole roast beans in the whirlpool and the fermenter.
beer.name: AB:17
beer.tips: Use freshly ground coffee for the best aromatic hit.

beer.desc: This tentacled terminator packs a punch - ten punches to be precise. Each hop addition adds to the intense layers of depth in this red rye IPA. Toasty caramel & cinder toffee from crystal malts, cacao richness from intensely roasted malt and the spiciness of rye. Zesty pithiness from Citra and the robust resin of Chinook. This small batch exclusive brew is up-front intensity matched with twisted complexity. Aged in Rye Whisky Casks.
food: Rocket and mozzarella salad with a cracked pepper dressing
Fried halibut with sweet potato fritters
beer.name: Barrel Aged Albino Squid Assassin
beer.tagline: Red Rye IPA Aged In Rye Whisky Cask.
beer.tips: 20% specialty malts in this grist can create problems in the run off. Be careful not to pull the bed down onto the plates.

beer.desc: A cherry imperial stout aged in ex- sherry whisky barrels. Based on the classic German Schwarzwald (Black Forest) dessert. Intense dark fruit flavours of cherry, plum, raisin and currant, coupled with deep bitter chocolate, espresso and a full- bodied coffee and cream character.
food: Roast duck in a cherry glaze
Chocolate torte with a dark fruit compote
beer.name: AB:13
beer.tips: To mimic the sherry cask ageing character, soak some oak chips in sherry for 48 hours then steep them in the beer after primary fermentation has finished.

beer.desc: Our Prototype Challenge sees us pit three new trial beers against each other. This Double IPA is packed with a blend of our favourite American hops and has a huge dry- hop aroma.
food: Hot Wings And Blue Cheese Dip
Sticky Toffee Pudding And Salted Caramel Ice Cream
beer.name: Prototype Double IPA
beer.tips: The hopping rate should leave a light residual haze in your beer after maturation. Don’t worry, this comes from the hop compounds, haze is taste.

beer.desc: Flavours and aromas you'd expect from a Stout, but brewed without dark malts. The full mouthfeel comes courtesy of wheat and oats, while smoked malt and the twist additions add the complex flavours normally provided by highly kilned malts.
food: Caramelised scallops with burnt apple puree
beer.name: AB:08
beer.tips: Add all twist ingredients to Fermentation Vessel once fermentation is complete. Don’t be afraid to add a little at a time and taste as you go. During mashing in first start with pale malt. Afterwards mix all malts evenly. Go with flaked oats during second half of mashing in process.

beer.desc: Invented by and brewed by Dan Bloxham, no matter what anyone else says. A medium bodied, bitter, US style stout, with a wasabi warmth, a subtle earthiness and a hint of soy sauce.
food: California sushi rolls with fresh crab and wasabi infused soy sauce
Spicy chilli and coriander Thai beef stew
beer.name: Mr.Miyagi's Wasabi Stout
beer.tagline: Spicy Stout Brewed By Aberdeen Bar Staff.
beer.tips: During mashing in use only pale malts, add flaked oats during the second half of the mashing process. If you can't get real wasabi, substitute for some horseradish to get the peppery heat in the beer.

beer.desc: BrewDog vs. Weihenstephan India Pale Weizen kicked off a new direction for our collaborations. We took a simple concept (by our standards) and teamed up with the oldest brewery in the world to brew a mash-up beer using the signature styles of both breweries. India Pale Weizen has classic base hefeweizen aromas and flavours of banana, clove and bubblegum, with a distinctive haziness. Layered on top of this is a tapestry of US citrus hop character. India Pale Weizen is a perfect symbiosis of traditional and modern brewing.
food: Waffles with caramelised apple and powdered sugar
beer.name: India Pale Weizen (w/ Weihenstephan)
beer.tips: Let the fermentation temperature creep up a couple of degrees higher than normal to create the characteristic banana and bubblegum aromas.

beer.desc: Our Equity Punk gypsy brewery - Beatnik Brewing Collective - voted for this recipe as their 2017 annual brew. A blonde stout brewed to export strength, the stout character comes from extra ingredients instead of dark malts.
beer.name: Blonde Export Stout
beer.tips: An oxymoron of a beer. The cocoa nibs are vital in providing that stout like flavour without the associated colour.

beer.desc: 5AM Saint's big brother. Dry- hopping with Chinook gave Hops Kill Nazis a full-on, instantly recognisable US hop character - huge resinous aromas (think giant redwood) with a bitter grapefruit edge. The caramel malts bring flavours of toffee and burnt sugar, which gave Hops Kill Nazis a big, complex malt base supporting the intense hopping.
food: Candied almond and blue cheese rocket salad
beer.name: Hops Kill Nazis
beer.tips: A red colour is a difficult hue to achieve in beer. Experiment with different amounts of Crystal malt to fine tune the colour.

beer.desc: Brewed exclusively for the Finnish market, this Hello My Name brew features a twist of flavour inspired by Finland.
food: Steamed cod with ginger and spring onions
beer.name: Hello My Name Is Sari
beer.tips: Instead of adding the blueberry juice in the kettle. Add fresh blueberries to your secondary fermenter, pitch The Yeast Bay's Melange Sour Blend and wait for 1 year.

beer.desc: East Coast Crush is a Vermont style pale ale, packaged and served using our custom LIVE beer dispense. A session Vermont IPA, with low background bitterness, loaded with intense juicy mango, pineapple, peach and pine.
beer.name: Small Batch: East Coast Crush
beer.tips: Vermont Yeast, whilst desirable for this style of beer, is not absolutely necessary. The murk of a NEIPA can be achieved by malt selection and your process.

beer.desc: The first beer that we brewed on our newly commissioned 5000 litre brewhouse in Fraserburgh 2009. A beer with the malt and body of an English bitter, but the heart and soul of vibrant citrus US hops.
beer.name: Skull Candy
beer.tips: Make sure your hops are well broken up and mixed in when added to the kettle for aroma additions. The wort is not boiling so is not agitating the hops to allow mixing. If the hops aren't steeped properly in the wort you won't get the maximum flavour impact.

beer.desc: Old world meets new in this trans-atlantic mash up of brewing ingredients. Belgian funk incorporates itself into the pithy, resin and grapefruit, with pineapple and banana rounding out a rambunctious avalanche of fruity hops.
beer.name: Punk Monk
beer.tips: Bottle condition and prime with a little bit more sugar than usual to attain those authentic fine Belgian bubbles.

beer.desc: Our crew designed it, and we bottled it just for ourselves! We chose an 8% red ale, mash hopped and first wort hopped with New Zealand origin hops.
beer.name: Crew Brew
beer.tips: Bring a few bottles to your local BrewDog bar when it's done and ask the staff if you got it right, they're the only ones who can tell you for sure! They'll also probably know of other homebrewers and beer enthusiasts nearby that you can link in with to share your experiences and get awesome first hand advice from.

beer.desc: Our anniversary stout was based on AB:04, one of our most sought after beers ever. This beer is slightly different each year, with subtle variations coming into play purely down to environmental and fermentation factors. What doesn't change is the rich dark chocolate, bitter coffee and chilli warmth of this monumental Stout.
beer.name: Dog B
beer.tips: Be really careful when mashing, as this amount of malts can get tough to sparge! Add honey into the boil, and naga chili and vanilla in maturation (soak them in some neutral spirit to sanitise).

beer.desc: We’ve split our bets with Casino Rye Ale and doubled up on the malt front, with barley and rye on the grain bill.
beer.name: Casino Rye Ale
beer.tips: We don't recommend roulette as a way to design beer. Spin the bottle is a much more sensible option. Make this beer with the freshest ingredients you can. Try to arrange brewday as close to delivery day as possible and throw 10 brewbucks on black 17 for us.
